questions.stem: The primary goal of defensive driving is to:
choices: Reduce risk by anticipating hazards and leaving time and space to react.
Arrive as quickly as possible by keeping up with the fastest traffic.
Focus mainly on your lane and ignore surrounding vehicles.
Rely on your vehicle’s safety features to prevent all crashes.
questions.answer: Reduce risk by anticipating hazards and leaving time and space to react.
questions.explanation: Defensive driving emphasizes risk reduction through anticipation, scanning, and space management—not speed or gadgets.

questions.stem: SIPDE stands for:
choices: Search, Identify, Predict, Decide, Execute
Scan, Inspect, Plan, Drive, Exit
See, Interpret, Proceed, Direct, Evaluate
Search, Indicate, Prepare, Drive, Ease
questions.answer: Search, Identify, Predict, Decide, Execute
questions.explanation: SIPDE is the classic defensive driving process to continuously manage hazards.

questions.stem: In the Smith System, “Aim high in steering” means:
choices: Look 12–15 seconds ahead to plan for what’s coming.
Keep your eyes fixed on the vehicle immediately ahead.
Focus only on the speedometer to manage speed.
Lower your seating position for better stability.
questions.answer: Look 12–15 seconds ahead to plan for what’s coming.
questions.explanation: A long visual lead time helps you detect and respond to hazards early.

questions.stem: On dry pavement, a minimum following distance for passenger cars is typically:
choices: 3–4 seconds
1 second
6–8 seconds
1 car length per 10 mph
questions.answer: 3–4 seconds
questions.explanation: Use a 3–4 second time gap in ideal conditions; add time in poor conditions.

questions.stem: Which situation calls for increasing your following distance?
choices: Rain or reduced visibility
Clear, dry, empty freeway
Daytime on a straight rural road
Slow neighborhood traffic with no pedestrians
questions.answer: Rain or reduced visibility
questions.explanation: Bad weather and limited visibility increase stopping distance and risk.

questions.stem: If a driver is tailgating you, the best response is to:
choices: Create extra space ahead and avoid sudden braking.
Brake hard to warn them to back off.
Speed up significantly to increase distance.
Weave to discourage their behavior.
questions.answer: Create extra space ahead and avoid sudden braking.
questions.explanation: Smoothing your own driving and increasing space ahead reduces the chance of a rear-end crash.

questions.stem: California’s basic speed law requires you to:
choices: Never drive faster than is safe for current conditions.
Drive at least the posted speed limit at all times.
Match the fastest traffic flow.
Use cruise control in all conditions.
questions.answer: Never drive faster than is safe for current conditions.
questions.explanation: Posted limits do not override the need to slow for traffic, weather, or visibility.

questions.stem: Good visual lead time in city driving is about:
choices: 12–15 seconds ahead
3–4 seconds ahead
5–7 seconds ahead
20–30 seconds ahead
questions.answer: 12–15 seconds ahead
questions.explanation: In urban areas, looking 12–15 seconds ahead helps anticipate intersections and hazards.

questions.stem: Before changing lanes on a freeway in California, you should signal for approximately:
choices: About 5 seconds
At least 1 second
Only after you begin the lane change
You do not need to signal on freeways
questions.answer: About 5 seconds
questions.explanation: A longer signal duration on freeways gives other drivers more time to see your intent.

questions.stem: In general, you should signal a turn in California at least:
choices: 100 feet before the turn
25 feet before the turn
After starting your turn
Only if other drivers are nearby
questions.answer: 100 feet before the turn
questions.explanation: Signaling early communicates your intentions and reduces conflicts.

questions.stem: To check blind spots before a lane change you should:
choices: Turn your head to look over the appropriate shoulder.
Rely only on your side mirrors.
Glance at the rearview mirror twice.
Honk to warn other drivers.
questions.answer: Turn your head to look over the appropriate shoulder.
questions.explanation: Head checks reveal vehicles that mirrors cannot show.

questions.stem: With ABS in an emergency stop, you should:
choices: Press the brake firmly and steer where you want to go.
Pump the brakes rapidly.
Apply the parking brake immediately.
Turn off the engine to stop faster.
questions.answer: Press the brake firmly and steer where you want to go.
questions.explanation: ABS prevents wheel lockup; keep steady pressure and maintain steering control.

questions.stem: If your vehicle begins to skid, you should first:
choices: Ease off the accelerator and look/steer to your intended path.
Brake as hard as possible immediately.
Turn the wheel opposite your intended path.
Accelerate to regain traction.
questions.answer: Ease off the accelerator and look/steer to your intended path.
questions.explanation: Reducing power helps tires regain grip; steer where you want the car to go.

questions.stem: If you have a tire blowout, you should:
choices: Grip the wheel, ease off the gas, avoid hard braking, and steer to a safe stop.
Brake hard immediately and steer sharply to the shoulder.
Accelerate to keep the car straight.
Turn off the ignition and coast to a stop.
questions.answer: Grip the wheel, ease off the gas, avoid hard braking, and steer to a safe stop.
questions.explanation: Smooth control prevents a spin or loss of control after a blowout.

questions.stem: If your right wheels drop off the pavement onto the shoulder, you should:
choices: Hold the wheel straight, slow down, and gently steer back when clear.
Jerk the wheel left immediately to return to the lane.
Accelerate hard to regain the roadway.
Brake hard while turning sharply.
questions.answer: Hold the wheel straight, slow down, and gently steer back when clear.
questions.explanation: Sudden sharp steering can cause a loss of control or rollover.

questions.stem: Following distance should be measured using:
choices: A fixed object on the road ahead and counting seconds.
The number of car lengths between vehicles.
Your speedometer reading.
A guess based on how it feels.
questions.answer: A fixed object on the road ahead and counting seconds.
questions.explanation: Counting seconds adjusts for speed and is more reliable than car lengths.

questions.stem: Typical driver reaction time is about:
choices: Around 1 second
Around 0.1 seconds
Around 3 seconds
Around 5 seconds
questions.answer: Around 1 second
questions.explanation: Plan for roughly a one‑second delay before braking begins—more if distracted or tired.

questions.stem: For general driving, the best default lane position is:
choices: Centered in the lane
Hugging the left line
Hugging the right line
Changing position constantly
questions.answer: Centered in the lane
questions.explanation: Centering maximizes space on both sides and reduces drift.

questions.stem: Approaching a ‘stale green’ light, you should:
choices: Cover the brake, scan for cross-traffic, and be prepared to stop.
Accelerate to beat the yellow.
Ignore crosswalks if no pedestrians are present.
Change lanes to the fastest lane.
questions.answer: Cover the brake, scan for cross-traffic, and be prepared to stop.
questions.explanation: A stale green may change; early preparation prevents rushed decisions.

questions.stem: When another vehicle is passing you, you should:
choices: Maintain lane and speed and allow space.
Speed up to prevent the pass.
Move into the shoulder to block.
Honk and change lanes immediately.
questions.answer: Maintain lane and speed and allow space.
questions.explanation: Holding steady helps the passing driver complete safely.
